hints.label: thm-su2-local-gauge-invariance
hints.title: Local SU(2)_weak Gauge Invariance
hints.content:
2008: :label: thm-su2-local-gauge-invariance
2009: 
2010: The path integral for the cloning amplitude is **locally gauge invariant** under SU(2)_weak transformations at each walker vertex.
2011: 
2012: **Setup:**
2013: 
2014: Define a **local SU(2) gauge transformation** at each walker vertex $i \in A_t$:
2015: 
2016: $$
2017: G_i \in \text{SU}(2), \quad G_i = \exp\left(i\sum_{a=1}^3 \beta^{(a)}(i) \frac{\sigma^a}{2}\right)
2018: $$
2019: 
2020: where $\beta^{(a)}(i) \in \mathbb{R}$ are three arbitrary real parameters and $\sigma^a$ are Pauli matrices.
2021: 
2022: **Transformation of Link Variables:**
2023: 
2024: The SU(2) phase on cloning edges is encoded in the **link variable**:
2025: 
2026: $$
2027: U_{ij} = \exp(i\theta_{ij}^{(\text{SU}(2))} \mathbf{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma})
2028: $$
2029: 
2030: where $\mathbf{n}$ is a unit vector in SU(2) space.
2031: 
2032: Under local gauge transformation:
2033: 
2034: $$
2035: U_{ij} \to U_{ij}' = G_i \cdot U_{ij} \cdot G_j^\dagger
2036: $$
2037: 
2038: **Physical Interpretation:**
2039: 
2040: The SU(2) gauge transformation rotates the weak isospin doublet:
2041: 
2042: $$
2043: |\Psi_{ij}\rangle = |{\uparrow}\rangle \otimes |\psi_i\rangle + |{\downarrow}\rangle \otimes |\psi_j\rangle \to |\Psi_{ij}'\rangle = (G_i \otimes I_{\text{div}}) |\Psi_{ij}\rangle
2044: $$
2045: 
2046: This mixes the "cloner" ($|{\uparrow}\rangle$) and "target" ($|{\downarrow}\rangle$) roles at each vertex independently.
2047: 
2048: **Step 1: Transformation of SU(2) Interaction Amplitude**
2049: 
2050: The SU(2) interaction amplitude from §7.5:
2051: 
2052: $$
2053: A_{ij}^{\text{SU}(2)} = \sqrt{P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{clone})}(j|i)} \cdot e^{i\theta_{ij}^{(\text{SU}(2))}}
2054: $$
2055: 
2056: Under gauge transformation, the **group element** transforms:
2057: 
2058: $$
2059: U_{ij}' = G_i \cdot U_{ij} \cdot G_j^\dagger
2060: $$
2061: 
2062: But $A_{ij}^{\text{SU}(2)}$ is a complex scalar, not a group element. We must embed it in SU(2):
2063: 
2064: $$
2065: A_{ij}^{\text{SU}(2)} \text{ corresponds to the matrix element } \langle \uparrow | U_{ij} | \uparrow \rangle
2066: $$
2067: 
2068: **Step 2: SU(2) Wilson Loops**
2069: 
2070: For a closed loop $\gamma = (i_0, i_1, \ldots, i_n = i_0)$ in the cloning graph, define:
2071: 
2072: $$
2073: U_\gamma = U_{i_0 i_1} \cdot U_{i_1 i_2} \cdot \ldots \cdot U_{i_{n-1} i_n}
2074: $$
2075: 
2076: The **SU(2) Wilson loop** is:
2077: 
2078: $$
2079: W_{\text{SU}(2)}[\gamma] = \frac{1}{2}\text{Tr}(U_\gamma)
2080: $$
2081: 
2082: Under gauge transformation:
2083: 
2084: $$
2085: U_\gamma' = (G_{i_0} U_{i_0 i_1} G_{i_1}^\dagger) \cdot (G_{i_1} U_{i_1 i_2} G_{i_2}^\dagger) \cdot \ldots \cdot (G_{i_{n-1}} U_{i_{n-1} i_0} G_{i_0}^\dagger)
2086: $$
2087: 
2088: $$
2089: = G_{i_0} \cdot U_{i_0 i_1} \cdot U_{i_1 i_2} \cdot \ldots \cdot U_{i_{n-1} i_0} \cdot G_{i_0}^\dagger = G_{i_0} \cdot U_\gamma \cdot G_{i_0}^\dagger
2090: $$
2091: 
2092: Using the cyclic property of the trace:
2093: 
2094: $$
2095: W'[\gamma] = \frac{1}{2}\text{Tr}(G_{i_0} U_\gamma G_{i_0}^\dagger) = \frac{1}{2}\text{Tr}(U_\gamma G_{i_0}^\dagger G_{i_0}) = \frac{1}{2}\text{Tr}(U_\gamma) = W[\gamma]
2096: $$
2097: 
2098: **SU(2) Wilson loops are gauge invariant!**
2099: 
2100: **Step 3: SU(2) Invariance of K_eff**
2101: 
2102: A crucial property: **SU(2) gauge transformations do not affect the U(1) dressing kernel**.
2103: 
2104: **Lemma**: The effective kernel $K_{\text{eff}}(i,j)$ is **SU(2)-invariant**.
2105: 
2106: **Proof**: From §7.5, the effective kernel is:
2107: 
2108: $$
2109: K_{\text{eff}}(i,j) = \sum_{k,m \in A_t} \sqrt{P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{div})}(k|i)} \sqrt{P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{div})}(m|j)} \sqrt{P_{\text{succ}}(S)} \cdot e^{i(\theta_{ik}^{(\text{U(1)})} + \theta_{jm}^{(\text{U(1)})} + S/\hbar_{\text{eff}})}
2110: $$
2111: 
2112: Every component of this expression depends **only** on the algorithmic space coordinates $\mathcal{Y} = \{(x_i, v_i, s_i)\}$:
2113: 
2114: 1. **Companion probabilities**: $P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{div})}(k|i) = \frac{e^{-d_{\text{alg}}(i,k)^2/(2\epsilon_d^2)}}{\sum_{k'} e^{-d_{\text{alg}}(i,k')^2/(2\epsilon_d^2)}}$ - depends on $d_{\text{alg}}(i,k) = \sqrt{\|x_i - x_k\|^2 + \lambda_{\text{alg}}\|v_i - v_k\|^2}$ only
2115: 2. **U(1) phases**: $\theta_{ik}^{(\text{U(1)})} = -\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i,k)^2}{2\epsilon_d^2\hbar_{\text{eff}}}$ - depends on $d_{\text{alg}}(i,k)$ only
2116: 3. **Success amplitude**: $P_{\text{succ}}(S)$ and $S = V_{\text{fit}}(i|k) - V_{\text{fit}}(j|m)$ - depend on fitness potentials
2117: 
2118: **Lemma (Fitness Potential Invariance)**: The fitness potential $V_{\text{fit}}(i|k)$ is SU(2)-invariant.
2119: 
2120: *Proof*: From {prf:ref}`def-fitness-potential-operator`, the fitness potential is constructed from Z-scores of raw rewards and diversity distances calculated over the entire alive set $A_t$:
2121: 
2122: $$
2123: V_{\text{fit}}(i|k) = \alpha \cdot Z_{\text{reward}}(i) + \beta \cdot Z_{\text{div}}(i, k)
2124: $$
2125: 
2126: where the Z-scores depend on:
2127: - Reward statistics: $\{r_j : j \in A_t\}$
2128: - Diversity distances: $\{d_{\text{alg}}(i, j) : j \in A_t\}$
2129: 
2130: The calculation for walker $i$ depends **only on its position** $(x_i, v_i)$ and its **statistical relation to the swarm**, not on its role as a potential cloner or target. The weak isospin state (cloner vs target) is an internal quantum number that does not affect algorithmic space coordinates. Therefore, $V_{\text{fit}}$ is a function on the algorithmic space only and is invariant under SU(2) transformations of the internal isospin state. ∎
2131: 
2132: **Crucially**: The SU(2) weak isospin transformation acts on the **internal quantum numbers** $(|\uparrow\rangle, |\downarrow\rangle)$ representing the cloning role (cloner vs target), NOT on the algorithmic space coordinates $(x, v, s)$.
2133: 
2134: Since $K_{\text{eff}}$ has **no dependence on weak isospin quantum numbers**, it is automatically invariant:
2135: 
2136: $$
2137: K_{\text{eff}}'(i,j) = K_{\text{eff}}(i,j) \quad \text{under SU(2) transformation}
2138: $$
2139: 
2140: **Physical interpretation**: The U(1) dressing describes fitness self-measurement through diversity companions. This measurement occurs in algorithmic space and is blind to the weak isospin state. The SU(2) transformation mixes cloner/target roles but does not affect where walkers are located or how they measure their fitness. ∎
2141: 
2142: **Step 4: Gauge-Invariant Observable - Total Interaction Probability from Mutual Pairing**
2143: 
2144: **Physical Principle: Mutual Pairing Constraint**
2145: 
2146: The cloning companion selection algorithm (see {doc}`../03_cloning.md` §3) uses a **random matching algorithm** that creates **mutually selected symmetric pairs**:
2147: 
2148: **Definition (Mutual Pairing)**:
2149: - If walker i selects walker j as its cloning companion, then walker j selects walker i as its cloning companion
2150: - This creates symmetric pairs $(i,j)$ where both $i \in \mathcal{C}_j$ and $j \in \mathcal{C}_i$
2151: - The pairing is symmetric: the pair $\{i, j\}$ is a single physical entity, not two separate directional relationships
2152: 
2153: **Consequence for Fitness Scores:**
2154: 
2155: For mutually paired walkers $(i,j)$, the relative fitness scores are:
2156: 
2157: $$
2158: s_i = \frac{V_{\text{fit}}(j) - V_{\text{fit}}(i)}{V_{\text{fit}}(i) + \epsilon}, \quad s_j = \frac{V_{\text{fit}}(i) - V_{\text{fit}}(j)}{V_{\text{fit}}(j) + \epsilon}
2159: $$
2160: 
2161: **Key properties:**
2162: 1. The numerators are **exact opposites**: $V_{\text{fit}}(j) - V_{\text{fit}}(i) = -(V_{\text{fit}}(i) - V_{\text{fit}}(j))$
2163: 2. The denominators are **strictly positive**: $V_{\text{fit}}(i) + \epsilon > 0$ and $V_{\text{fit}}(j) + \epsilon > 0$ (fitness potential bounded below by $\eta^{(\alpha+\beta)} > 0$)
2164: 3. Therefore, $s_i$ and $s_j$ have **opposite signs**: if $s_i > 0$, then $s_j < 0$ (mutually exclusive)
2165: 4. **Fitness determines direction**: The walker with lower fitness clones to the walker with higher fitness
2166: 
2167: **Physical Interpretation:**
2168: 
2169: The cloning direction is **deterministically determined by fitness**, not probabilistic:
2170: - If $V_{\text{fit}}(i) > V_{\text{fit}}(j)$: walker j clones to i (direction: $j \to i$)
2171: - If $V_{\text{fit}}(j) > V_{\text{fit}}(i)$: walker i clones to j (direction: $i \to j$)
2172: - **Exactly one direction occurs physically**
2173: 
2174: **Why Individual P_clone(i→j) is NOT SU(2) Invariant:**
2175: 
2176: Under SU(2) transformation $G_i, G_j \in \text{SU}(2)$, the amplitude transforms as:
2177: 
2178: $$
2179: A_{ij}'^{\text{SU}(2)} = \langle \uparrow | G_i U_{ij} G_j^\dagger | \uparrow \rangle
2180: $$
2181: 
2182: For general $G_i, G_j$, the transformation **mixes** the $|\uparrow\rangle$ (cloner) and $|\downarrow\rangle$ (target) basis states:
2183: 
2184: $$
2185: G_i | \uparrow \rangle = \alpha_i |\uparrow\rangle + \beta_i |\downarrow\rangle
2186: $$
2187: 
2188: Therefore, the matrix element changes:
2189: 
2190: $$
2191: |A_{ij}'^{\text{SU}(2)}|^2 \neq |A_{ij}^{\text{SU}(2)}|^2 \quad \text{in general}
2192: $$
2193: 
2194: The directional cloning probability $P_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)$ is **NOT gauge invariant** because it depends on which basis state we label as "cloner" ($|\uparrow\rangle$) vs "target" ($|\downarrow\rangle$).
2195: 
2196: **The Gauge-Invariant Observable:**
2197: 
2198: Due to mutual pairing, the physical observable is **not** "probability of i→j" or "probability of j→i" separately. The physical observable is:
2199: 
2200: $$
2201: P_{\text{total}}(i,j) := P_{\text{interaction}}(\{i,j\}) = \text{probability that the mutually paired walkers } \{i,j\} \text{ interact via cloning}
2202: $$
2203: 
2204: This is a **single physical quantity** representing the interaction of the symmetric pair, independent of our choice of basis labels.
2205: 
2206: Mathematically, this is computed as:
2207: 
2208: $$
2209: P_{\text{total}}(i,j) = P_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) + P_{\text{clone}}(j \to i)
2210: $$
2211: 
2212: but the physical interpretation is: "probability that pair $\{i,j\}$ undergoes a cloning interaction (in the direction determined by fitness)".
2213: 
2214: **Theorem**: $P_{\text{total}}(i,j)$ is SU(2) gauge invariant.
2215: 
2216: **Proof (Method 1: State and Operator Transformation)**:
2217: 
2218: The composite state for mutually paired walkers is:
2219: 
2220: $$
2221: |\Psi_{ij}\rangle = |\uparrow\rangle \otimes |\psi_i\rangle + |\downarrow\rangle \otimes |\psi_j\rangle
2222: $$
2223: 
2224: where $|\psi_i\rangle, |\psi_j\rangle$ are the U(1) diversity dressing states (SU(2)-invariant, as shown in Step 3).
2225: 
2226: The projection operator onto the interaction subspace is:
2227: 
2228: $$
2229: \hat{\Pi}_{\text{interaction}} = \hat{\Pi}(i \to j) + \hat{\Pi}(j \to i)
2230: $$
2231: 
2232: where:
2233: 
2234: $$
2235: \hat{\Pi}(i \to j) = \Theta(\hat{S}_{ij}) \cdot \hat{P}_{\uparrow} \otimes I, \quad \hat{\Pi}(j \to i) = \Theta(-\hat{S}_{ij}) \cdot \hat{P}_{\downarrow} \otimes I
2236: $$
2237: 
2238: **Due to mutual pairing**: $s_i$ and $s_j$ have opposite signs, so $\Theta(s_i) + \Theta(s_j) = 1$ (exactly one is 1, the other is 0).
2239: 
2240: Therefore:
2241: 
2242: $$
2243: \hat{\Pi}_{\text{interaction}} = \begin{cases}
2244: \hat{P}_{\uparrow} \otimes I & \text{if } s_i > 0 \text{ (i clones j)} \\
2245: \hat{P}_{\downarrow} \otimes I & \text{if } s_j > 0 \text{ (j clones i)}
2246: \end{cases}
2247: $$
2248: 
2249: The observable is:
2250: 
2251: $$
2252: P_{\text{total}}(i,j) = \langle \Psi_{ij} | \hat{\Pi}_{\text{interaction}} | \Psi_{ij} \rangle
2253: $$
2254: 
2255: Under local SU(2) gauge transformation at vertices i and j:
2256: - State transforms: $|\Psi_{ij}'\rangle = (G_i \otimes G_j \otimes I_{\text{div}})|\Psi_{ij}\rangle$
2257: - Operator transforms: $\hat{\Pi}'_{\text{interaction}} = (G_i \otimes G_j \otimes I_{\text{div}}) \hat{\Pi}_{\text{interaction}} (G_i^\dagger \otimes G_j^\dagger \otimes I_{\text{div}})$
2258: 
2259: The transformed observable is:
2260: 
2261: $$
2262: P'_{\text{total}}(i,j) = \langle \Psi'_{ij} | \hat{\Pi}'_{\text{interaction}} | \Psi'_{ij} \rangle
2263: $$
2264: 
2265: Substituting the transformations:
2266: 
2267: $$
2268: P'_{\text{total}}(i,j) = \langle \Psi_{ij} | (G_i^\dagger \otimes G_j^\dagger \otimes I) (G_i \otimes G_j \otimes I) \hat{\Pi}_{\text{interaction}} (G_i^\dagger \otimes G_j^\dagger \otimes I)(G_i \otimes G_j \otimes I) | \Psi_{ij} \rangle
2269: $$
2270: 
2271: Using unitarity of $G_i$ and $G_j$: $(G_i^\dagger \otimes G_j^\dagger)(G_i \otimes G_j) = (G_i^\dagger G_i) \otimes (G_j^\dagger G_j) = I \otimes I = I$:
2272: 
2273: $$
2274: P'_{\text{total}}(i,j) = \langle \Psi_{ij} | \hat{\Pi}_{\text{interaction}} | \Psi_{ij} \rangle = P_{\text{total}}(i,j)
2275: $$
2276: 
2277: Therefore, $P_{\text{total}}(i,j)$ is **SU(2) gauge invariant**. ∎
2278: 
2279: **Physical Interpretation:**
2280: 
2281: The gauge invariance of $P_{\text{total}}(i,j)$ encodes the physical content of the SU(2) symmetry:
2282: 
2283: 1. **Mutual pairing defines a single physical observable**: The quantity $P_{\text{total}}(i,j)$ represents the interaction probability for the symmetric pair $\{i,j\}$, not a sum of two independent processes
2284: 
2285: 2. **The projector encodes deterministic cloning**: Due to mutual pairing, $\hat{\Pi}_{\text{interaction}}$ projects onto the realized cloning direction (determined by fitness), which is a physical event
2286: 
2287: 3. **SU(2) transformations represent gauge freedom**: The transformations relabel basis states ($|\uparrow\rangle \leftrightarrow |\downarrow\rangle$) without changing the underlying physics
2288: 
2289: 4. **Invariance expresses physical consistency**: Relabeling the mathematical description (gauge transformation) cannot change the probability of a physical event (cloning interaction)
2290: 
2291: This structure characterizes a genuine gauge theory: unphysical gauge freedom combined with physically meaningful gauge-invariant observables.
2292: 
2293: **Conclusion:**
2294: 
2295: The SU(2) structure is a **genuine non-Abelian local gauge symmetry** arising from the mutual pairing structure of the cloning algorithm. The **symmetric interaction probability** $P_{\text{total}}(i,j)$ is the physical gauge-invariant observable.
2296: 
2297: Individual directional probabilities $P_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)$ depend on the gauge choice (the choice of basis for isospin states), but the **total interaction probability for the mutually paired walkers** is gauge-invariant.
2298: 
2299: **Physical Meaning:**
2300: 
2301: The SU(2) gauge freedom represents the arbitrary choice of which basis states we call $|\uparrow\rangle$ (cloner) vs $|\downarrow\rangle$ (target) in our mathematical description. Physics doesn't care about this labeling - the mutual pairing constraint ensures that:
2302: 
2303: 1. The pair $\{i, j\}$ is a single physical entity (symmetric partners)
2304: 2. Fitness determines which direction actually occurs (deterministic)
2305: 3. The probability of interaction is independent of our choice of basis labels (gauge-invariant)
hints.section: ## 7. Quantum Embedding: Four-Walker Interference and Path Integral Structure
hints.raw_directive:
2005: :::
2006: 
2007: :::{prf:theorem} Local SU(2)_weak Gauge Invariance
2008: :label: thm-su2-local-gauge-invariance
2009: 
2010: The path integral for the cloning amplitude is **locally gauge invariant** under SU(2)_weak transformations at each walker vertex.
2011: 
2012: **Setup:**
2013: 
2014: Define a **local SU(2) gauge transformation** at each walker vertex $i \in A_t$:
2015: 
2016: $$
2017: G_i \in \text{SU}(2), \quad G_i = \exp\left(i\sum_{a=1}^3 \beta^{(a)}(i) \frac{\sigma^a}{2}\right)
2018: $$
2019: 
2020: where $\beta^{(a)}(i) \in \mathbb{R}$ are three arbitrary real parameters and $\sigma^a$ are Pauli matrices.
2021: 
2022: **Transformation of Link Variables:**
2023: 
2024: The SU(2) phase on cloning edges is encoded in the **link variable**:
2025: 
2026: $$
2027: U_{ij} = \exp(i\theta_{ij}^{(\text{SU}(2))} \mathbf{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{\sigma})
2028: $$
2029: 
2030: where $\mathbf{n}$ is a unit vector in SU(2) space.
2031: 
2032: Under local gauge transformation:
2033: 
2034: $$
2035: U_{ij} \to U_{ij}' = G_i \cdot U_{ij} \cdot G_j^\dagger
2036: $$
2037: 
2038: **Physical Interpretation:**
2039: 
2040: The SU(2) gauge transformation rotates the weak isospin doublet:
2041: 
2042: $$
2043: |\Psi_{ij}\rangle = |{\uparrow}\rangle \otimes |\psi_i\rangle + |{\downarrow}\rangle \otimes |\psi_j\rangle \to |\Psi_{ij}'\rangle = (G_i \otimes I_{\text{div}}) |\Psi_{ij}\rangle
2044: $$
2045: 
2046: This mixes the "cloner" ($|{\uparrow}\rangle$) and "target" ($|{\downarrow}\rangle$) roles at each vertex independently.
2047: 
2048: **Step 1: Transformation of SU(2) Interaction Amplitude**
2049: 
2050: The SU(2) interaction amplitude from §7.5:
2051: 
2052: $$
2053: A_{ij}^{\text{SU}(2)} = \sqrt{P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{clone})}(j|i)} \cdot e^{i\theta_{ij}^{(\text{SU}(2))}}
2054: $$
2055: 
2056: Under gauge transformation, the **group element** transforms:
2057: 
2058: $$
2059: U_{ij}' = G_i \cdot U_{ij} \cdot G_j^\dagger
2060: $$
2061: 
2062: But $A_{ij}^{\text{SU}(2)}$ is a complex scalar, not a group element. We must embed it in SU(2):
2063: 
2064: $$
2065: A_{ij}^{\text{SU}(2)} \text{ corresponds to the matrix element } \langle \uparrow | U_{ij} | \uparrow \rangle
2066: $$
2067: 
2068: **Step 2: SU(2) Wilson Loops**
2069: 
2070: For a closed loop $\gamma = (i_0, i_1, \ldots, i_n = i_0)$ in the cloning graph, define:
2071: 
2072: $$
2073: U_\gamma = U_{i_0 i_1} \cdot U_{i_1 i_2} \cdot \ldots \cdot U_{i_{n-1} i_n}
2074: $$
2075: 
2076: The **SU(2) Wilson loop** is:
2077: 
2078: $$
2079: W_{\text{SU}(2)}[\gamma] = \frac{1}{2}\text{Tr}(U_\gamma)
2080: $$
2081: 
2082: Under gauge transformation:
2083: 
2084: $$
2085: U_\gamma' = (G_{i_0} U_{i_0 i_1} G_{i_1}^\dagger) \cdot (G_{i_1} U_{i_1 i_2} G_{i_2}^\dagger) \cdot \ldots \cdot (G_{i_{n-1}} U_{i_{n-1} i_0} G_{i_0}^\dagger)
2086: $$
2087: 
2088: $$
2089: = G_{i_0} \cdot U_{i_0 i_1} \cdot U_{i_1 i_2} \cdot \ldots \cdot U_{i_{n-1} i_0} \cdot G_{i_0}^\dagger = G_{i_0} \cdot U_\gamma \cdot G_{i_0}^\dagger
2090: $$
2091: 
2092: Using the cyclic property of the trace:
2093: 
2094: $$
2095: W'[\gamma] = \frac{1}{2}\text{Tr}(G_{i_0} U_\gamma G_{i_0}^\dagger) = \frac{1}{2}\text{Tr}(U_\gamma G_{i_0}^\dagger G_{i_0}) = \frac{1}{2}\text{Tr}(U_\gamma) = W[\gamma]
2096: $$
2097: 
2098: **SU(2) Wilson loops are gauge invariant!**
2099: 
2100: **Step 3: SU(2) Invariance of K_eff**
2101: 
2102: A crucial property: **SU(2) gauge transformations do not affect the U(1) dressing kernel**.
2103: 
2104: **Lemma**: The effective kernel $K_{\text{eff}}(i,j)$ is **SU(2)-invariant**.
2105: 
2106: **Proof**: From §7.5, the effective kernel is:
2107: 
2108: $$
2109: K_{\text{eff}}(i,j) = \sum_{k,m \in A_t} \sqrt{P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{div})}(k|i)} \sqrt{P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{div})}(m|j)} \sqrt{P_{\text{succ}}(S)} \cdot e^{i(\theta_{ik}^{(\text{U(1)})} + \theta_{jm}^{(\text{U(1)})} + S/\hbar_{\text{eff}})}
2110: $$
2111: 
2112: Every component of this expression depends **only** on the algorithmic space coordinates $\mathcal{Y} = \{(x_i, v_i, s_i)\}$:
2113: 
2114: 1. **Companion probabilities**: $P_{\text{comp}}^{(\text{div})}(k|i) = \frac{e^{-d_{\text{alg}}(i,k)^2/(2\epsilon_d^2)}}{\sum_{k'} e^{-d_{\text{alg}}(i,k')^2/(2\epsilon_d^2)}}$ - depends on $d_{\text{alg}}(i,k) = \sqrt{\|x_i - x_k\|^2 + \lambda_{\text{alg}}\|v_i - v_k\|^2}$ only
2115: 2. **U(1) phases**: $\theta_{ik}^{(\text{U(1)})} = -\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i,k)^2}{2\epsilon_d^2\hbar_{\text{eff}}}$ - depends on $d_{\text{alg}}(i,k)$ only
2116: 3. **Success amplitude**: $P_{\text{succ}}(S)$ and $S = V_{\text{fit}}(i|k) - V_{\text{fit}}(j|m)$ - depend on fitness potentials
2117: 
2118: **Lemma (Fitness Potential Invariance)**: The fitness potential $V_{\text{fit}}(i|k)$ is SU(2)-invariant.
2119: 
2120: *Proof*: From {prf:ref}`def-fitness-potential-operator`, the fitness potential is constructed from Z-scores of raw rewards and diversity distances calculated over the entire alive set $A_t$:
2121: 
2122: $$
2123: V_{\text{fit}}(i|k) = \alpha \cdot Z_{\text{reward}}(i) + \beta \cdot Z_{\text{div}}(i, k)
2124: $$
2125: 
2126: where the Z-scores depend on:
2127: - Reward statistics: $\{r_j : j \in A_t\}$
2128: - Diversity distances: $\{d_{\text{alg}}(i, j) : j \in A_t\}$
2129: 
2130: The calculation for walker $i$ depends **only on its position** $(x_i, v_i)$ and its **statistical relation to the swarm**, not on its role as a potential cloner or target. The weak isospin state (cloner vs target) is an internal quantum number that does not affect algorithmic space coordinates. Therefore, $V_{\text{fit}}$ is a function on the algorithmic space only and is invariant under SU(2) transformations of the internal isospin state. ∎
2131: 
2132: **Crucially**: The SU(2) weak isospin transformation acts on the **internal quantum numbers** $(|\uparrow\rangle, |\downarrow\rangle)$ representing the cloning role (cloner vs target), NOT on the algorithmic space coordinates $(x, v, s)$.
2133: 
2134: Since $K_{\text{eff}}$ has **no dependence on weak isospin quantum numbers**, it is automatically invariant:
2135: 
2136: $$
2137: K_{\text{eff}}'(i,j) = K_{\text{eff}}(i,j) \quad \text{under SU(2) transformation}
2138: $$
2139: 
2140: **Physical interpretation**: The U(1) dressing describes fitness self-measurement through diversity companions. This measurement occurs in algorithmic space and is blind to the weak isospin state. The SU(2) transformation mixes cloner/target roles but does not affect where walkers are located or how they measure their fitness. ∎
2141: 
2142: **Step 4: Gauge-Invariant Observable - Total Interaction Probability from Mutual Pairing**
2143: 
2144: **Physical Principle: Mutual Pairing Constraint**
2145: 
2146: The cloning companion selection algorithm (see {doc}`../03_cloning.md` §3) uses a **random matching algorithm** that creates **mutually selected symmetric pairs**:
2147: 
2148: **Definition (Mutual Pairing)**:
2149: - If walker i selects walker j as its cloning companion, then walker j selects walker i as its cloning companion
2150: - This creates symmetric pairs $(i,j)$ where both $i \in \mathcal{C}_j$ and $j \in \mathcal{C}_i$
2151: - The pairing is symmetric: the pair $\{i, j\}$ is a single physical entity, not two separate directional relationships
2152: 
2153: **Consequence for Fitness Scores:**
2154: 
2155: For mutually paired walkers $(i,j)$, the relative fitness scores are:
2156: 
2157: $$
2158: s_i = \frac{V_{\text{fit}}(j) - V_{\text{fit}}(i)}{V_{\text{fit}}(i) + \epsilon}, \quad s_j = \frac{V_{\text{fit}}(i) - V_{\text{fit}}(j)}{V_{\text{fit}}(j) + \epsilon}
2159: $$
2160: 
2161: **Key properties:**
2162: 1. The numerators are **exact opposites**: $V_{\text{fit}}(j) - V_{\text{fit}}(i) = -(V_{\text{fit}}(i) - V_{\text{fit}}(j))$
2163: 2. The denominators are **strictly positive**: $V_{\text{fit}}(i) + \epsilon > 0$ and $V_{\text{fit}}(j) + \epsilon > 0$ (fitness potential bounded below by $\eta^{(\alpha+\beta)} > 0$)
2164: 3. Therefore, $s_i$ and $s_j$ have **opposite signs**: if $s_i > 0$, then $s_j < 0$ (mutually exclusive)
2165: 4. **Fitness determines direction**: The walker with lower fitness clones to the walker with higher fitness
2166: 
2167: **Physical Interpretation:**
2168: 
2169: The cloning direction is **deterministically determined by fitness**, not probabilistic:
2170: - If $V_{\text{fit}}(i) > V_{\text{fit}}(j)$: walker j clones to i (direction: $j \to i$)
2171: - If $V_{\text{fit}}(j) > V_{\text{fit}}(i)$: walker i clones to j (direction: $i \to j$)
2172: - **Exactly one direction occurs physically**
2173: 
2174: **Why Individual P_clone(i→j) is NOT SU(2) Invariant:**
2175: 
2176: Under SU(2) transformation $G_i, G_j \in \text{SU}(2)$, the amplitude transforms as:
2177: 
2178: $$
2179: A_{ij}'^{\text{SU}(2)} = \langle \uparrow | G_i U_{ij} G_j^\dagger | \uparrow \rangle
2180: $$
2181: 
2182: For general $G_i, G_j$, the transformation **mixes** the $|\uparrow\rangle$ (cloner) and $|\downarrow\rangle$ (target) basis states:
2183: 
2184: $$
2185: G_i | \uparrow \rangle = \alpha_i |\uparrow\rangle + \beta_i |\downarrow\rangle
2186: $$
2187: 
2188: Therefore, the matrix element changes:
2189: 
2190: $$
2191: |A_{ij}'^{\text{SU}(2)}|^2 \neq |A_{ij}^{\text{SU}(2)}|^2 \quad \text{in general}
2192: $$
2193: 
2194: The directional cloning probability $P_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)$ is **NOT gauge invariant** because it depends on which basis state we label as "cloner" ($|\uparrow\rangle$) vs "target" ($|\downarrow\rangle$).
2195: 
2196: **The Gauge-Invariant Observable:**
2197: 
2198: Due to mutual pairing, the physical observable is **not** "probability of i→j" or "probability of j→i" separately. The physical observable is:
2199: 
2200: $$
2201: P_{\text{total}}(i,j) := P_{\text{interaction}}(\{i,j\}) = \text{probability that the mutually paired walkers } \{i,j\} \text{ interact via cloning}
2202: $$
2203: 
2204: This is a **single physical quantity** representing the interaction of the symmetric pair, independent of our choice of basis labels.
2205: 
2206: Mathematically, this is computed as:
2207: 
2208: $$
2209: P_{\text{total}}(i,j) = P_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) + P_{\text{clone}}(j \to i)
2210: $$
2211: 
2212: but the physical interpretation is: "probability that pair $\{i,j\}$ undergoes a cloning interaction (in the direction determined by fitness)".
2213: 
2214: **Theorem**: $P_{\text{total}}(i,j)$ is SU(2) gauge invariant.
2215: 
2216: **Proof (Method 1: State and Operator Transformation)**:
2217: 
2218: The composite state for mutually paired walkers is:
2219: 
2220: $$
2221: |\Psi_{ij}\rangle = |\uparrow\rangle \otimes |\psi_i\rangle + |\downarrow\rangle \otimes |\psi_j\rangle
2222: $$
2223: 
2224: where $|\psi_i\rangle, |\psi_j\rangle$ are the U(1) diversity dressing states (SU(2)-invariant, as shown in Step 3).
2225: 
2226: The projection operator onto the interaction subspace is:
2227: 
2228: $$
2229: \hat{\Pi}_{\text{interaction}} = \hat{\Pi}(i \to j) + \hat{\Pi}(j \to i)
2230: $$
2231: 
2232: where:
2233: 
2234: $$
2235: \hat{\Pi}(i \to j) = \Theta(\hat{S}_{ij}) \cdot \hat{P}_{\uparrow} \otimes I, \quad \hat{\Pi}(j \to i) = \Theta(-\hat{S}_{ij}) \cdot \hat{P}_{\downarrow} \otimes I
2236: $$
2237: 
2238: **Due to mutual pairing**: $s_i$ and $s_j$ have opposite signs, so $\Theta(s_i) + \Theta(s_j) = 1$ (exactly one is 1, the other is 0).
2239: 
2240: Therefore:
2241: 
2242: $$
2243: \hat{\Pi}_{\text{interaction}} = \begin{cases}
2244: \hat{P}_{\uparrow} \otimes I & \text{if } s_i > 0 \text{ (i clones j)} \\
2245: \hat{P}_{\downarrow} \otimes I & \text{if } s_j > 0 \text{ (j clones i)}
2246: \end{cases}
2247: $$
2248: 
2249: The observable is:
2250: 
2251: $$
2252: P_{\text{total}}(i,j) = \langle \Psi_{ij} | \hat{\Pi}_{\text{interaction}} | \Psi_{ij} \rangle
2253: $$
2254: 
2255: Under local SU(2) gauge transformation at vertices i and j:
2256: - State transforms: $|\Psi_{ij}'\rangle = (G_i \otimes G_j \otimes I_{\text{div}})|\Psi_{ij}\rangle$
2257: - Operator transforms: $\hat{\Pi}'_{\text{interaction}} = (G_i \otimes G_j \otimes I_{\text{div}}) \hat{\Pi}_{\text{interaction}} (G_i^\dagger \otimes G_j^\dagger \otimes I_{\text{div}})$
2258: 
2259: The transformed observable is:
2260: 
2261: $$
2262: P'_{\text{total}}(i,j) = \langle \Psi'_{ij} | \hat{\Pi}'_{\text{interaction}} | \Psi'_{ij} \rangle
2263: $$
2264: 
2265: Substituting the transformations:
2266: 
2267: $$
2268: P'_{\text{total}}(i,j) = \langle \Psi_{ij} | (G_i^\dagger \otimes G_j^\dagger \otimes I) (G_i \otimes G_j \otimes I) \hat{\Pi}_{\text{interaction}} (G_i^\dagger \otimes G_j^\dagger \otimes I)(G_i \otimes G_j \otimes I) | \Psi_{ij} \rangle
2269: $$
2270: 
2271: Using unitarity of $G_i$ and $G_j$: $(G_i^\dagger \otimes G_j^\dagger)(G_i \otimes G_j) = (G_i^\dagger G_i) \otimes (G_j^\dagger G_j) = I \otimes I = I$:
2272: 
2273: $$
2274: P'_{\text{total}}(i,j) = \langle \Psi_{ij} | \hat{\Pi}_{\text{interaction}} | \Psi_{ij} \rangle = P_{\text{total}}(i,j)
2275: $$
2276: 
2277: Therefore, $P_{\text{total}}(i,j)$ is **SU(2) gauge invariant**. ∎
2278: 
2279: **Physical Interpretation:**
2280: 
2281: The gauge invariance of $P_{\text{total}}(i,j)$ encodes the physical content of the SU(2) symmetry:
2282: 
2283: 1. **Mutual pairing defines a single physical observable**: The quantity $P_{\text{total}}(i,j)$ represents the interaction probability for the symmetric pair $\{i,j\}$, not a sum of two independent processes
2284: 
2285: 2. **The projector encodes deterministic cloning**: Due to mutual pairing, $\hat{\Pi}_{\text{interaction}}$ projects onto the realized cloning direction (determined by fitness), which is a physical event
2286: 
2287: 3. **SU(2) transformations represent gauge freedom**: The transformations relabel basis states ($|\uparrow\rangle \leftrightarrow |\downarrow\rangle$) without changing the underlying physics
2288: 
2289: 4. **Invariance expresses physical consistency**: Relabeling the mathematical description (gauge transformation) cannot change the probability of a physical event (cloning interaction)
2290: 
2291: This structure characterizes a genuine gauge theory: unphysical gauge freedom combined with physically meaningful gauge-invariant observables.
2292: 
2293: **Conclusion:**
2294: 
2295: The SU(2) structure is a **genuine non-Abelian local gauge symmetry** arising from the mutual pairing structure of the cloning algorithm. The **symmetric interaction probability** $P_{\text{total}}(i,j)$ is the physical gauge-invariant observable.
2296: 
2297: Individual directional probabilities $P_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)$ depend on the gauge choice (the choice of basis for isospin states), but the **total interaction probability for the mutually paired walkers** is gauge-invariant.
2298: 
2299: **Physical Meaning:**
2300: 
2301: The SU(2) gauge freedom represents the arbitrary choice of which basis states we call $|\uparrow\rangle$ (cloner) vs $|\downarrow\rangle$ (target) in our mathematical description. Physics doesn't care about this labeling - the mutual pairing constraint ensures that:
2302: 
2303: 1. The pair $\{i, j\}$ is a single physical entity (symmetric partners)
2304: 2. Fitness determines which direction actually occurs (deterministic)
2305: 3. The probability of interaction is independent of our choice of basis labels (gauge-invariant)
2306:

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-1684
hints.title: Non-Abelian Nature of SU(2)
hints.content:
2311: :class: important
2312: 
2313: **Key differences from U(1):**
2314: 
2315: 1. **Matrix-valued**: SU(2) link variables are 2×2 matrices, not just phases
2316: 2. **Non-commutative**: $U_{ij} U_{jk} \neq U_{jk} U_{ij}$ - **path ordering matters**
2317: 3. **Self-interaction**: The field strength has cubic terms: $F_{\mu\nu} \sim \partial A + g[A, A]$
2318: 
2319: **Physical consequence:**
2320: 
2321: Non-Abelian gauge bosons (W/Z bosons) **interact with themselves**, unlike photons. This leads to:
2322: - Asymptotic freedom (strong force weakens at short distances)
2323: - Confinement (quarks cannot be isolated)
2324: - Mass generation via Higgs mechanism

hints.label: thm-sn-gauge-invariance
hints.title: S_N Permutation Gauge Invariance
hints.content:
2330: :label: thm-sn-gauge-invariance
2331: 
2332: The **fundamental gauge symmetry** of the Fragile Gas is the **S_N permutation group**. All physical observables are S_N-invariant by construction.
2333: 
2334: **Statement:**
2335: 
2336: For any permutation $\sigma \in S_N$ and any swarm configuration $\mathcal{S} = (w_1, \ldots, w_N)$:
2337: 
2338: $$
2339: P_{\text{clone}}(\sigma \cdot \mathcal{S}) = P_{\text{clone}}(\mathcal{S})
2340: $$
2341: 
2342: and more generally, all observables $f(\mathcal{S})$ satisfy:
2343: 
2344: $$
2345: f(\sigma \cdot \mathcal{S}) = f(\mathcal{S})
2346: $$
2347: 
2348: **Proof:**
2349: 
2350: This is proven rigorously in {doc}`../12_gauge_theory_adaptive_gas.md`:
2351: 
2352: 1. **Gauge-invariant dynamics** (Theorem 6.4.4 in {doc}`../09_symmetries_adaptive_gas.md`): The transition operator $\Psi_t$ commutes with S_N:
2353:    $$
2354:    \sigma \circ \Psi_t = \Psi_t \circ \sigma \quad \forall \sigma \in S_N
2355:    $$
2356: 
2357: 2. **Configuration space orbifold** ({doc}`../12_gauge_theory_adaptive_gas.md` §1): Physical states live in $\mathcal{M}_{\text{config}} = \Sigma_N / S_N$
2358: 
2359: 3. **Braid holonomy** ({doc}`../12_gauge_theory_adaptive_gas.md` §3.4): Wilson loops measure holonomy $\text{Hol}(\gamma) = \rho([\gamma]) \in S_N$ for closed paths
2360: 
2361: 4. **Observables descend to quotient** ({doc}`../12_gauge_theory_adaptive_gas.md` Theorem 2.4.1): All physical observables are S_N-invariant functions
2362: 
2363: **Physical Interpretation:**
2364: 
2365: Walker labels are **pure gauge** - they're arbitrary bookkeeping indices with no physical content. The S_N gauge symmetry is the mathematical expression of this fact.
2366: 
2367: **Wilson Loops from Braid Topology:**

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-1746
hints.title: Three-Tier Gauge Structure
hints.content:
2373: :class: important
2374: 
2375: **Summary of the complete gauge structure:**
2376: 
2377: | Symmetry | Type | Origin | Observables | Wilson Loops |
2378: |----------|------|--------|-------------|--------------|
2379: | **S_N** | Local, discrete | Walker labels arbitrary | S_N-invariant functions | Braid holonomy $\text{Hol}(\gamma)$ |
2380: | **SU(2)_weak** | Local, continuous | Cloning isospin doublet | Trace over weak isospin | SU(2) path-ordered exponential |
2381: | **U(1)_fitness** | Global, continuous | Absolute fitness scale | None (global phase) | None (global symmetry) |
2382: 
2383: **Hierarchy:**
2384: 
2385: 1. **S_N is fundamental**: Discrete gauge group from first principles

hints.label: thm-su3-strong-sector
hints.title: SU(3) Color Symmetry from Viscous Force Vector
hints.content:
2394: :label: thm-su3-strong-sector
2395: 
2396: The **viscous force vector** $\mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(i) \in \mathbb{R}^d$ defines an **SU(3) color charge** symmetry acting on a three-component color state.
2397: 
2398: **1. Color Charge State Vector:**
2399: 
2400: For each walker i, define the **color state** as a real three-component vector derived from the viscous force components:
2401: 
2402: $$
2403: \mathbf{c}_i = \begin{pmatrix} F_x^{(\text{visc})}(i) \\ F_y^{(\text{visc})}(i) \\ F_z^{(\text{visc})}(i) \end{pmatrix} \in \mathbb{R}^3
2404: 
2405: $$
2406: 
2407: where $\mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(i) = \nu \sum_{j \in A_t} K_\rho(x_i, x_j)(v_j - v_i)$ from {prf:ref}`def-hybrid-sde`.
2408: 
2409: **2. Complexification (Momentum-Phase Encoding):**
2410: 
2411: Construct a **complex color state** in $\mathbb{C}^3$ (fundamental representation of SU(3)) using **momentum as phase**:
2412: 
2413: $$
2414: |\Psi_i^{(\text{color})}\rangle = \frac{1}{\|\mathbf{c}_i\|} \begin{pmatrix} c_i^{(x)} \\ c_i^{(y)} \\ c_i^{(z)} \end{pmatrix} \in \mathbb{C}^3
2415: 
2416: $$
2417: 
2418: where the complexification encodes **both force (magnitude) and momentum (phase)**:
2419: 
2420: $$
2421: c_i^{(\alpha)} = F_\alpha^{(\text{visc})}(i) \cdot \exp\left(i\frac{m v_i^{(\alpha)}}{\hbar_{\text{eff}}}\right), \quad \alpha \in \{x, y, z\}
2422: 
2423: $$
2424: 
2425: **Physical interpretation:**
2426: - **Magnitude** $|c_i^{(\alpha)}| = |F_\alpha^{(\text{visc})}(i)|$: Spatial coupling through viscous force
2427: - **Phase** $\arg(c_i^{(\alpha)}) = mv_i^{(\alpha)}/\hbar_{\text{eff}}$: Canonical quantum momentum phase (de Broglie)
2428: - **Full phase space**: $(F_{\text{visc}}, \mathbf{v}) \in \mathbb{R}^3 \times \mathbb{R}^3$ → $\mathbf{c} \in \mathbb{C}^3$ (6 real DOF)
2429: 
2430: This provides a **bijective map** between 6D phase space $(x, v)$ and 3D complex color space:
2431: - 3 magnitudes: Force components $F_x, F_y, F_z$ (spatial structure)
2432: - 3 phases: Momentum components $p_x = mv_x, p_y = mv_y, p_z = mv_z$ (velocity structure)
2433: 
2434: **Advantages:**
2435: 1. **Information-complete**: Captures full $(x, v)$ phase space, not just spatial configuration
2436: 2. **Physically motivated**: Uses canonical quantum phase $p/\hbar$ (de Broglie relation $\lambda = h/p$)
2437: 3. **Gauge-covariant dynamics**: Phase evolution couples velocity changes to gauge rotation
2438: 4. **Reconstructible**: Can extract both $\mathbf{F}_{\text{visc}}$ and $\mathbf{v}$ from $\mathbf{c}$ uniquely
2439: 
2440: **3. SU(3) Gluon Field:**
2441: 
2442: The interaction between walkers i and j is mediated by **SU(3) gluon matrices** $U_{ij} \in \text{SU}(3)$:
2443: 
2444: $$
2445: U_{ij} = \exp\left(i \sum_{a=1}^8 g_a \lambda_a A_{ij}^a\right)
2446: 
2447: $$
2448: 
2449: where:
2450: - $\lambda_a$ are the eight Gell-Mann matrices (generators of SU(3))
2451: - $A_{ij}^a$ are gluon field components derived from the emergent manifold geometry
2452: - $g_a$ are coupling constants
2453: 
2454: **4. Color Transformation:**
2455: 
2456: Under SU(3) gauge transformations:
2457: 
2458: $$
2459: |\Psi_i^{(\text{color})}\rangle \to U_i |\Psi_i^{(\text{color})}\rangle, \quad U_i \in \text{SU}(3)
2460: 
2461: $$
2462: 
2463: $$
2464: U_{ij} \to U_i U_{ij} U_j^\dagger
2465: 
2466: $$
2467: 
2468: **5. Confinement Analogue:**
2469: 
2470: The viscous coupling strength $\nu K_\rho(x_i, x_j)$ acts as a **color confinement potential**:
2471: - **Short range** ($d(x_i, x_j) < \rho$): Strong coupling (confinement)
2472: - **Long range** ($d(x_i, x_j) \gg \rho$): Exponential suppression (asymptotic freedom)
2473: 
2474: $$
2475: K_\rho(x_i, x_j) = \exp\left(-\frac{d(x_i, x_j)^2}{2\rho^2}\right)
2476: 
2477: $$
2478: 
2479: **6. Time Evolution (Gauge-Covariant Dynamics):**
2480: 
2481: The color state evolves according to:
2482: 
2483: $$
2484: \frac{dc_i^{(\alpha)}}{dt} = \exp\left(i\frac{mv_\alpha}{\hbar_{\text{eff}}}\right) \left[\frac{dF_\alpha^{(\text{visc})}}{dt} + i\frac{m a_\alpha}{\hbar_{\text{eff}}} F_\alpha^{(\text{visc})}\right] + ig \sum_{a=1}^8 A_0^a (T^a c_i)^{(\alpha)}
2485: 
2486: $$
2487: 
2488: where:
2489: - $\frac{dF_\alpha^{(\text{visc})}}{dt}$: Spatial force evolution (viscous coupling changes)
2490: - $a_\alpha = \frac{dv_\alpha}{dt}$: Acceleration (velocity evolution)
2491: - $A_0^a$: Temporal gluon field components
2492: - $T^a$: Gell-Mann matrices (SU(3) generators)
2493: 
2494: **Physical interpretation:**
2495: - **First term**: Change in viscous force (spatial dynamics)
2496: - **Second term**: Velocity change creates phase rotation (kinematic coupling)
2497: - **Third term**: Gauge field rotation (color dynamics)
2498: 
2499: All three contributions are essential for complete gauge-covariant evolution.
2500: 
2501: **7. Physical Interpretation:**
2502: 
2503: - **Color charge**: Complex three-vector $\mathbf{c}_i$ encoding $(F_{\text{visc}}, \mathbf{v})$
2504: - **Gluons**: SU(3) matrices $U_{ij}$ mediating viscous coupling
2505: - **Confinement**: Walkers remain "bound" within $\rho$-neighborhood

hints.label: def-su3-gluon-field
hints.title: SU(3) Gluon Field Components from Manifold Geometry
hints.content:
2511: :label: def-su3-gluon-field
2512: 
2513: The eight gluon field components $A_{ij}^a$ for $a = 1, \ldots, 8$ are constructed from the emergent Riemannian metric $g_{\mu\nu}(x)$:
2514: 
2515: **1. Metric Tensor:**
2516: 
2517: $$
2518: g_{\mu\nu}(x) = \delta_{\mu\nu} + \frac{1}{\epsilon_\Sigma^2} \frac{\partial^2 V_{\text{fit}}}{\partial x^\mu \partial x^\nu}(x)
2519: 
2520: $$
2521: 
2522: from the regularized Hessian diffusion (see {prf:ref}`def-hybrid-sde`).
2523: 
2524: **2. Christoffel Symbols (Connection Coefficients):**
2525: 
2526: $$
2527: \Gamma^\lambda_{\mu\nu}(x) = \frac{1}{2} g^{\lambda\rho}(x) \left(\frac{\partial g_{\rho\mu}}{\partial x^\nu} + \frac{\partial g_{\rho\nu}}{\partial x^\mu} - \frac{\partial g_{\mu\nu}}{\partial x^\rho}\right)
2528: 
2529: $$
2530: 
2531: **3. Gluon Field Components:**
2532: 
2533: The SU(3) gluon field $A_{ij}^a$ is derived from the Christoffel symbols projected onto the Gell-Mann basis:
2534: 
2535: $$
2536: A_{ij}^a = \text{Tr}\left[\lambda_a \cdot \Gamma(x_i, x_j)\right]
2537: 
2538: $$
2539: 
2540: where $\Gamma(x_i, x_j)$ is the parallel transport operator from walker i to walker j along geodesic.
2541: 
2542: **Storage in Fractal Set:**
2543: 
2544: Each IG edge $(n_{i,t}, n_{j,t})$ stores:
2545: - Gluon field: $\mathbf{A}_{ij} = (A_{ij}^1, \ldots, A_{ij}^8) \in \mathbb{R}^8$

hints.label: thm-fermionic-z2-symmetry
hints.title: Fermionic Statistics from Antisymmetric Cloning
hints.content:
2553: :label: thm-fermionic-z2-symmetry
2554: 
2555: Walkers exhibit **fermionic behavior** due to the antisymmetric ±1 sign flip in the cloning interaction, realizing a **Z₂ symmetry** analogous to the Pauli Exclusion Principle.
2556: 
2557: **1. Antisymmetric Cloning Potential:**
2558: 
2559: From Section 6 (IG edge definition), the cloning potential is **antisymmetric**:
2560: 
2561: $$
2562: V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) = \Phi_j - \Phi_i = -V_{\text{clone}}(j \to i)
2563: 
2564: $$
2565: 
2566: This creates a **sign flip** under walker exchange: $V_{\text{clone}}(i \leftrightarrow j) = -V_{\text{clone}}(i, j)$
2567: 
2568: **2. Z₂ Symmetry:**
2569: 
2570: Define the **exchange operator** $\hat{P}_{ij}$ that swaps walkers i and j:
2571: 
2572: $$
2573: \hat{P}_{ij} V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) = V_{\text{clone}}(j \to i) = -V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)
2574: 
2575: $$
2576: 
2577: This is a **Z₂ symmetry**: $\hat{P}_{ij}^2 = \mathbb{1}$ with eigenvalues $\pm 1$.
2578: 
2579: **Fermionic sector**: States with eigenvalue $-1$ (antisymmetric under exchange)
2580: 
2581: $$
2582: \hat{P}_{ij} |\Psi(i, j)\rangle = -|\Psi(i, j)\rangle
2583: 
2584: $$
2585: 
2586: **3. Pauli Exclusion Principle Analogue:**
2587: 
2588: Two walkers **cannot occupy the same state** $(x, v)$:
2589: 
2590: **Algorithmic exclusion**: If $x_i \approx x_j$ and $v_i \approx v_j$, then:
2591: 
2592: $$
2593: d_{\text{alg}}(i, j) \to 0 \implies \theta_{ij}^{(\text{clone})} \to 0
2594: 
2595: $$
2596: 
2597: $$
2598: V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) = \Phi_j - \Phi_i \approx 0
2599: 
2600: $$
2601: 
2602: Therefore $P_{\text{succ}}(S \approx 0) \approx 1/2$ (no preference to clone), effectively **excluding** identical states.
2603: 
2604: **4. Fermionic Propagator:**
2605: 
2606: The cloning amplitude for fermions has an antisymmetric propagator:
2607: 
2608: $$
2609: G_F(i, j) = \frac{1}{E_j - E_i + i\epsilon} \cdot \text{sign}(V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j))
2610: 
2611: $$
2612: 
2613: where $E_i = V_{\text{fit}}(i|k)$ is the "energy" of walker i.
2614: 
2615: **5. Spin Statistics Connection:**
2616: 
2617: The antisymmetric fitness coupling $V_{\text{clone}}(i \leftrightarrow j) = -V_{\text{clone}}(i,j)$ combined with the SU(2) weak isospin doublet structure implies walkers are **spin-1/2 fermions**:
2618: 
2619: $$
2620: |\Psi_{\text{total}}(i,j)\rangle = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \left(|\text{Clone}\rangle_i |\text{Persist}\rangle_j - |\text{Persist}\rangle_i |\text{Clone}\rangle_j\right)
2621: 
2622: $$

hints.content:
2626: 
2627: :::{prf:proof}
2628: **Antisymmetry proof**:
2629: 
2630: Under walker exchange $i \leftrightarrow j$:
2631: 
2632: $$
2633: \Psi(i \to j) = \psi_{ij}^{(\text{clone})} \cdot \sum_{k,m} [\psi_{ik}^{(\text{div})} \cdot \psi_{jm}^{(\text{div})} \cdot \psi_{\text{succ}}(S(i,j,k,m))]
2634: 
2635: $$
2636: 
2637: $$
2638: \Psi(j \to i) = \psi_{ji}^{(\text{clone})} \cdot \sum_{k,m} [\psi_{jk}^{(\text{div})} \cdot \psi_{im}^{(\text{div})} \cdot \psi_{\text{succ}}(S(j,i,k,m))]
2639: 
2640: $$
2641: 
2642: Since $S(j,i,k,m) = V_{\text{fit}}(j|k) - V_{\text{fit}}(i|m) = -S(i,j,m,k)$:
2643: 
2644: $$
2645: \psi_{\text{succ}}(S(j,i,k,m)) = \sqrt{P_{\text{succ}}(-S)} \cdot e^{-iS/\hbar_{\text{eff}}}
2646: 
2647: $$
2648: 
2649: For a symmetric sigmoid $P_{\text{succ}}(-S) = 1 - P_{\text{succ}}(S)$, the total amplitude transforms as:
2650: 
2651: $$
2652: \Psi(j \to i) \approx -\Psi(i \to j) \quad \text{(antisymmetric)}
2653: 
2654: $$

hints.label: thm-emergent-general-relativity
hints.title: Emergent Spacetime Curvature from Fitness Hessian
hints.content:
2662: :label: thm-emergent-general-relativity
2663: 
2664: The algorithm generates a **curved Riemannian manifold** $(\mathcal{X}, g)$ that models **general relativity**, with metric tensor defined by the Hessian of the fitness potential.
2665: 
2666: **1. Emergent Metric Tensor:**
2667: 
2668: The metric $g_{\mu\nu}(x, S)$ on state space $\mathcal{X}$ is given by:
2669: 
2670: $$
2671: g_{\mu\nu}(x, S) = \delta_{\mu\nu} + \frac{1}{\epsilon_\Sigma^2} H_{\mu\nu}^{V_{\text{fit}}}(x)
2672: 
2673: $$
2674: 
2675: where $H_{\mu\nu}^{V_{\text{fit}}}(x) = \frac{\partial^2 V_{\text{fit}}}{\partial x^\mu \partial x^\nu}$ is the **Hessian** of the fitness potential.
2676: 
2677: **Physical interpretation**:
2678: - Flat metric $\delta_{\mu\nu}$: Euclidean background geometry
2679: - Hessian perturbation: Curvature induced by fitness landscape
2680: - Regularization $\epsilon_\Sigma$: Planck length scale
2681: 
2682: **2. Christoffel Symbols (Gravitational Connection):**
2683: 
2684: $$
2685: \Gamma^\lambda_{\mu\nu}(x) = \frac{1}{2} g^{\lambda\rho}(x) \left(\partial_\nu g_{\rho\mu} + \partial_\mu g_{\rho\nu} - \partial_\rho g_{\mu\nu}\right)
2686: 
2687: $$
2688: 
2689: These define the **geodesic equation** (walker trajectories in curved space):
2690: 
2691: $$
2692: \frac{d^2 x^\lambda}{dt^2} + \Gamma^\lambda_{\mu\nu} \frac{dx^\mu}{dt} \frac{dx^\nu}{dt} = 0
2693: 
2694: $$
2695: 
2696: **3. Riemann Curvature Tensor:**
2697: 
2698: $$
2699: R^\rho_{\sigma\mu\nu}(x) = \partial_\mu \Gamma^\rho_{\nu\sigma} - \partial_\nu \Gamma^\rho_{\mu\sigma} + \Gamma^\rho_{\mu\lambda} \Gamma^\lambda_{\nu\sigma} - \Gamma^\rho_{\nu\lambda} \Gamma^\lambda_{\mu\sigma}
2700: 
2701: $$
2702: 
2703: **4. Ricci Tensor and Scalar Curvature:**
2704: 
2705: $$
2706: R_{\mu\nu}(x) = R^\lambda_{\mu\lambda\nu}, \quad R(x) = g^{\mu\nu} R_{\mu\nu}
2707: 
2708: $$
2709: 
2710: **5. Einstein Field Equations Analogue:**
2711: 
2712: The fitness potential acts as a **stress-energy tensor** $T_{\mu\nu}$:
2713: 
2714: $$
2715: R_{\mu\nu} - \frac{1}{2} g_{\mu\nu} R = \frac{8\pi G_{\text{eff}}}{\epsilon_\Sigma^4} T_{\mu\nu}^{(\text{fitness})}
2716: 
2717: $$
2718: 
2719: where:
2720: 
2721: $$
2722: T_{\mu\nu}^{(\text{fitness})} = \frac{\partial V_{\text{fit}}}{\partial x^\mu} \frac{\partial V_{\text{fit}}}{\partial x^\nu} - \frac{1}{2} g_{\mu\nu} \|\nabla V_{\text{fit}}\|^2
2723: 
2724: $$
2725: 
2726: **Physical interpretation**:
2727: - Matter/energy → Fitness gradient $\nabla V_{\text{fit}}$
2728: - Spacetime curvature → Hessian $\nabla^2 V_{\text{fit}}$
2729: - Gravitational constant $G_{\text{eff}} \sim \epsilon_\Sigma^4/N$ (emergent)
2730: 
2731: **6. Geodesic Deviation (Tidal Forces):**
2732: 
2733: Two nearby walkers at positions $x_i$ and $x_j = x_i + \xi$ experience **geodesic deviation**:
2734: 
2735: $$
2736: \frac{D^2 \xi^\mu}{Dt^2} = -R^\mu_{\nu\rho\sigma} v^\nu \xi^\rho v^\sigma
2737: 
2738: $$

hints.label: def-curvature-storage
hints.title: Storage of Curvature Tensor in Fractal Set
hints.content:
2744: :label: def-curvature-storage
2745: 
2746: The Riemann curvature tensor $R^\rho_{\sigma\mu\nu}(x_i)$ at each walker position is stored in the Fractal Set:
2747: 
2748: **Node attributes** (scalars):
2749: - Ricci scalar: $R(n_{i,t}) = R(x_i(t))$
2750: - Metric determinant: $\det(g)(n_{i,t}) = \det(g_{\mu\nu}(x_i))$
2751: 
2752: **CST edge attributes** (spinors):
2753: - Christoffel symbols: $\Gamma^\lambda_{\mu\nu}(n_{i,t})$ (rank-3 tensor, stored as spinor components)
2754: - Ricci tensor: $R_{\mu\nu}(n_{i,t})$ (symmetric 2-tensor, stored as spinor)
2755: 
2756: **Full Riemann tensor**: Stored as **spinor representation** on CST edges. The rank-4 tensor $R^\rho_{\sigma\mu\nu}$ is encoded via its spinor equivalent using the Riemann-spinor correspondence.
2757: 
2758: **Dimension**: For $d=3$ spatial dimensions, $R^\rho_{\sigma\mu\nu}$ has $3^4 = 81$ components, but symmetries reduce to **20 independent components**. These are encoded in a spinor representation to maintain frame-covariance.
2759: 
2760: **Rationale**: Storing curvature as **spinors** (rather than tensors) is essential for:
2761: 1. **Frame-covariance**: Spinors transform intrinsically under Lorentz transformations, unlike tensors which require position-dependent Jacobians

2752: **CST edge attributes** (spinors):
2753: - Christoffel symbols: $\Gamma^\lambda_{\mu\nu}(n_{i,t})$ (rank-3 tensor, stored as spinor components)
2754: - Ricci tensor: $R_{\mu\nu}(n_{i,t})$ (symmetric 2-tensor, stored as spinor)
2755: 
2756: **Full Riemann tensor**: Stored as **spinor representation** on CST edges. The rank-4 tensor $R^\rho_{\sigma\mu\nu}$ is encoded via its spinor equivalent using the Riemann-spinor correspondence.

hints.label: def-two-spinor-formalism
hints.title: Two-Spinor Formalism for 4D Spacetime
hints.content:
2767: :label: def-two-spinor-formalism
2768: 
2769: To encode curvature tensors in spinor form, we use the **two-spinor formalism** (Penrose & Rindler), which provides a natural isomorphism between 4D Minkowski vectors and $2 \times 2$ Hermitian matrices.
2770: 
2771: **1. Spinor Index Structure:**
2772: 
2773: **Unprimed spinors**: $\psi^A$, $A \in \{0, 1\}$ (2 components)
2774: - Transform under $SL(2, \mathbb{C})$ matrices $S^A{}_B$
2775: - Complex 2-component objects
2776: 
2777: **Primed spinors**: $\chi^{A'}$, $A' \in \{0', 1'\}$ (2 components)
2778: - Transform under $\bar{S}^{A'}{}_{B'}$ (complex conjugate of $S$)
2779: - Represent independent helicity states
2780: 
2781: **Relation to Lorentz group**: The proper orthochronous Lorentz group $SO^+(1,3)$ is locally isomorphic to $SL(2, \mathbb{C})/\{\pm I\}$. Spinors provide the faithful **double cover** (Spin(1,3)).
2782: 
2783: **2. Index Raising and Lowering:**
2784: 
2785: **Levi-Civita symbols:**
2786: 
2787: $$
2788: \epsilon_{AB} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \quad
2789: \epsilon^{AB} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}
2790: $$
2791: 
2792: with $\epsilon_{AB} \epsilon^{BC} = \delta^C_A$ and similarly for primed indices.
2793: 
2794: **Index operations:**
2795: 
2796: $$
2797: \psi_A = \epsilon_{AB} \psi^B, \quad \psi^A = \epsilon^{AB} \psi_B
2798: $$
2799: 
2800: $$
2801: \chi_{A'} = \epsilon_{A'B'} \chi^{B'}, \quad \chi^{A'} = \epsilon^{A'B'} \chi_{B'}
2802: $$
2803: 
2804: **3. Soldering Forms (Spinor-Vector Correspondence):**
2805: 
2806: The **Pauli matrices** (with Minkowski signature) provide the soldering:
2807: 
2808: $$
2809: \sigma^{AA'}_\mu = (\sigma^0, \sigma^1, \sigma^2, \sigma^3), \quad
2810: \sigma^0 = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}, \quad
2811: \sigma^i = \text{(Pauli matrices)}
2812: $$
2813: 
2814: Explicitly:
2815: 
2816: $$
2817: \sigma^{AA'}_0 = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}, \quad
2818: \sigma^{AA'}_1 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \quad
2819: \sigma^{AA'}_2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & -i \\ i & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \quad
2820: \sigma^{AA'}_3 = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}
2821: $$
2822: 
2823: **Inverse soldering:**
2824: 
2825: $$
2826: \tilde{\sigma}_\mu^{AA'} = g_{\mu\nu} \eta^{AA'BB'} \sigma^{BB'}_\nu
2827: $$
2828: 
2829: where $\eta^{AA'BB'} = \epsilon^{AB} \epsilon^{A'B'}$.
2830: 
2831: **4. Spinor-Vector Isomorphism:**
2832: 
2833: Any 4-vector $V^\mu$ can be represented as a mixed-index spinor:
2834: 
2835: $$
2836: V^{AA'} = V^\mu \sigma^{AA'}_\mu
2837: $$
2838: 
2839: This provides a Hermitian $2 \times 2$ matrix:
2840: 
2841: $$
2842: V^{AA'} = \begin{pmatrix} V^0 + V^3 & V^1 - iV^2 \\ V^1 + iV^2 & V^0 - V^3 \end{pmatrix}
2843: $$
2844: 
2845: **Inverse map:**
2846: 
2847: $$
2848: V^\mu = \frac{1}{2} \text{Tr}(\sigma_\mu V^{AA'})
2849: $$
2850: 
2851: **5. Spinor Products and Contractions:**
2852: 
2853: **Spinor inner product** (antisymmetric):
2854: 
2855: $$
2856: \langle \psi | \chi \rangle = \psi^A \chi_A = \psi^A \epsilon_{AB} \chi^B = \psi^0 \chi^1 - \psi^1 \chi^0
2857: $$
2858: 
2859: **Vector norm from spinor**:
2860: 
2861: $$
2862: g_{\mu\nu} V^\mu V^\nu = \det(V^{AA'}) = V^{AA'} V_{AA'}
2863: $$
2864: 
2865: **6. Transformation Laws:**
2866: 
2867: Under a Lorentz transformation $\Lambda \in SO^+(1,3)$ with corresponding $S \in SL(2, \mathbb{C})$:
2868: 
2869: **Unprimed spinors:**
2870: 
2871: $$
2872: \psi'^A = S^A{}_B \psi^B
2873: $$
2874: 
2875: **Primed spinors:**
2876: 
2877: $$
2878: \chi'^{A'} = \bar{S}^{A'}{}_{B'} \chi^{B'}
2879: $$
2880: 
2881: **Mixed spinors (vectors):**
2882: 
2883: $$
2884: V'^{AA'} = S^A{}_B \bar{S}^{A'}{}_{B'} V^{BB'}
2885: $$
2886: 
2887: This reproduces the standard Lorentz transformation: $V'^\mu = \Lambda^\mu{}_\nu V^\nu$.
2888: 
2889: **7. Relation to Dirac Spinors:**
2890: 
2891: A Dirac spinor $\Psi \in \mathbb{C}^4$ decomposes into two 2-component Weyl spinors:
2892: 
2893: $$
2894: \Psi = \begin{pmatrix} \psi^A \\ \bar{\chi}_{A'} \end{pmatrix}
2895: $$
2896:

hints.label: def-riemann-spinor-encoding
hints.title: Riemann Tensor Spinor Encoding (Corrected)
hints.content:
2902: :label: def-riemann-spinor-encoding
2903: 
2904: The Riemann curvature tensor $R^\rho_{\sigma\mu\nu}$ is encoded as a spinor using the **Riemann-spinor correspondence** via the curvature spinor $\Psi_R$.
2905: 
2906: **1. Riemann Tensor Decomposition:**
2907: 
2908: In 4D spacetime, the Riemann tensor decomposes into three independent pieces:
2909: 
2910: $$
2911: R^\rho_{\sigma\mu\nu} = C^\rho_{\sigma\mu\nu} + \frac{1}{2}(g^\rho_\mu S_{\sigma\nu} - g^\rho_\nu S_{\sigma\mu} - g_{\sigma\mu} S^\rho_\nu + g_{\sigma\nu} S^\rho_\mu) + \frac{\Lambda}{6}(g^\rho_\mu g_{\sigma\nu} - g^\rho_\nu g_{\sigma\mu})
2912: $$
2913: 
2914: where:
2915: - $C^\rho_{\sigma\mu\nu}$: **Weyl curvature tensor** (10 independent real components, conformally invariant, traceless)
2916: - $S_{\mu\nu} = R_{\mu\nu} - \frac{1}{4}g_{\mu\nu}R$: **Trace-free Ricci tensor** (9 independent real components)
2917: - $\Lambda = \frac{R}{24}$: **Ricci scalar** (normalized, 1 real component)
2918: 
2919: **Total: 10 + 9 + 1 = 20 independent real components** ✓
2920: 
2921: **Bianchi identity**: The decomposition automatically accounts for the first Bianchi identity, giving exactly 20 DOFs.
2922: 
2923: **2. Two-Spinor Encoding:**
2924: 
2925: Using the two-spinor formalism ({prf:ref}`def-two-spinor-formalism`), the curvature decomposes into three spinorial objects:
2926: 
2927: **Weyl spinor** $\Psi_{ABCD}$:
2928: - Totally symmetric in 4 unprimed indices: $\Psi_{(ABCD)}$
2929: - **5 complex components** (10 real) encoding the Weyl tensor
2930: 
2931: **Trace-free Ricci spinor** $\Phi_{ABA'B'}$:
2932: - Hermitian in mixed indices: $\Phi_{(AB)(A'B')} = \overline{\Phi_{A'B'AB}}$
2933: - **3 complex + 3 real components** (9 real) encoding the traceless Ricci tensor
2934: 
2935: **Ricci scalar** $\Lambda \in \mathbb{R}$:
2936: - **1 real component**
2937: 
2938: **Total in spinor form**: 5 complex + 3 complex + 4 real = **8 complex + 4 real = 20 real** ✓
2939: 
2940: **3. Explicit Spinor Components:**
2941: 
2942: **Weyl spinor** (5 complex, 10 real):
2943: 
2944: $$
2945: \Psi_{ABCD} = \begin{cases}
2946: \Psi_{0000}, \Psi_{0001}, \Psi_{0011}, \Psi_{0111}, \Psi_{1111} & \text{(5 independent complex components)}
2947: \end{cases}
2948: $$
2949: 
2950: **Symmetry**: $\Psi_{ABCD} = \Psi_{(ABCD)}$ (totally symmetric).
2951: 
2952: **Relation to Weyl tensor**:
2953: 
2954: $$
2955: C_{\mu\nu\rho\sigma} = \Psi_{ABCD} \sigma^{AB}_{\mu\nu} \sigma^{CD}_{\rho\sigma} + \bar{\Psi}_{A'B'C'D'} \bar{\sigma}^{A'B'}_{\mu\nu} \bar{\sigma}^{C'D'}_{\rho\sigma}
2956: $$
2957: 
2958: where $\sigma^{AB}_{\mu\nu} = \sigma^A_{[\mu} \sigma^B_{\nu]}$ are antisymmetrized soldering forms.
2959: 
2960: **Trace-free Ricci spinor** (3 complex + 3 real = 9 real):
2961: 
2962: $$
2963: \Phi_{ABA'B'} = \Phi_{(AB)(A'B')} \quad \text{(Hermitian: } \Phi_{ABA'B'} = \overline{\Phi_{A'B'AB}})
2964: $$
2965: 
2966: Components:
2967: 
2968: $$
2969: \begin{aligned}
2970: &\text{Real diagonal}: \Phi_{00,0'0'}, \, \Phi_{01,0'1'}, \, \Phi_{11,1'1'} \quad (3 \text{ real}) \\
2971: &\text{Complex off-diagonal}: \Phi_{00,0'1'}, \, \Phi_{01,0'0'}, \, \Phi_{01,1'1'} \quad (3 \text{ complex} = 6 \text{ real})
2972: \end{aligned}
2973: $$
2974: 
2975: **Relation to traceless Ricci**:
2976: 
2977: $$
2978: S_{\mu\nu} = \Phi_{ABA'B'} \sigma^{AB}_\mu \bar{\sigma}^{A'B'}_\nu
2979: $$
2980: 
2981: where $S_{\mu\nu} = R_{\mu\nu} - \frac{1}{4}g_{\mu\nu}R$ is the trace-free part.
2982: 
2983: **Ricci scalar**:
2984: 
2985: $$
2986: \Lambda = \frac{R}{24} \in \mathbb{R} \quad (1 \text{ real component})
2987: $$
2988: 
2989: **4. Storage in $\mathbb{C}^{16}$:**
2990: 
2991: The combined curvature spinor is stored as:
2992: 
2993: $$
2994: \Psi_R^{(16)} = \begin{pmatrix}
2995: \Psi_{0000} \\
2996: \Psi_{0001} \\
2997: \Psi_{0011} \\
2998: \Psi_{0111} \\
2999: \Psi_{1111} \\
3000: \Phi_{00,0'0'} \\
3001: \Phi_{01,0'1'} \\
3002: \Phi_{11,1'1'} \\
3003: \Phi_{00,0'1'} \\
3004: \Phi_{01,0'0'} \\
3005: \Phi_{01,1'1'} \\
3006: \Lambda \\
3007: 0 \\
3008: 0 \\
3009: 0 \\
3010: 0
3011: \end{pmatrix} \in \mathbb{C}^{16}
3012: $$
3013: 
3014: **Slot usage:**
3015: - Slots 1-5: Weyl spinor (5 complex)
3016: - Slots 6-8: Real diagonal of Ricci spinor (3 real, stored as real parts)
3017: - Slots 9-11: Off-diagonal Ricci spinor (3 complex)
3018: - Slot 12: Ricci scalar (1 real, stored as real part)
3019: - Slots 13-16: Padding (required for SO(10) gauge connection compatibility)
3020: 
3021: **Effective storage**: 11 complex slots used (22 real components), with 20 being independent after accounting for Hermiticity.
3022: 
3023: **5. Lorentz Transformation Properties:**
3024: 
3025: Under a Lorentz transformation $\Lambda \in SO^+(1,3)$ with corresponding $S \in SL(2, \mathbb{C})$ (from {prf:ref}`def-two-spinor-formalism`):
3026: 
3027: **Weyl spinor transforms as:**
3028: 
3029: $$
3030: \Psi'_{ABCD} = S^E{}_A S^F{}_B S^G{}_C S^H{}_D \Psi_{EFGH}
3031: $$
3032: 
3033: (4 unprimed indices → 4 factors of $S$)
3034: 
3035: **Trace-free Ricci spinor transforms as:**
3036: 
3037: $$
3038: \Phi'_{ABA'B'} = S^C{}_A S^D{}_B \bar{S}^{C'}{}_{A'} \bar{S}^{D'}{}_{B'} \Phi_{CDC'D'}
3039: $$
3040: 
3041: (2 unprimed + 2 primed indices → mixed transformation)
3042: 
3043: **Ricci scalar is invariant:**
3044: 
3045: $$
3046: \Lambda' = \Lambda
3047: $$
3048: 
3049: (Scalar curvature is a Lorentz scalar)
3050: 
3051: **6. Reconstruction Formulas:**
3052: 
3053: Given the spinor components $\Psi_{ABCD}$, $\Phi_{ABA'B'}$, and $\Lambda$, reconstruct the full Riemann tensor:
3054: 
3055: **Self-dual and anti-self-dual bivectors:**
3056: 
3057: First, define the self-dual 2-form spinor basis:
3058: 
3059: $$
3060: \sigma_{\mu\nu}^{AB} = \sigma_\mu^{AA'} \sigma_\nu^{BA'} - \sigma_\nu^{AA'} \sigma_\mu^{BA'}
3061: $$
3062: 
3063: and its complex conjugate:
3064: 
3065: $$
3066: \bar{\sigma}_{\mu\nu}^{A'B'} = \bar{\sigma}_\mu^{AA'} \bar{\sigma}_\nu^{AB'} - \bar{\sigma}_\nu^{AA'} \bar{\sigma}_\mu^{AB'}
3067: $$
3068: 
3069: These satisfy $\sigma_{\mu\nu}^{AB} = \sigma_{[\mu\nu]}^{AB}$ (antisymmetric in $\mu, \nu$) and $\sigma_{\mu\nu}^{AB} = \sigma_{\mu\nu}^{(AB)}$ (symmetric in $A, B$).
3070: 
3071: **Step 1: Reconstruct Weyl tensor**
3072: 
3073: $$
3074: C_{\mu\nu\rho\sigma} = \Psi_{ABCD} \sigma_{\mu\nu}^{AB} \sigma_{\rho\sigma}^{CD} \epsilon_{A'B'} \epsilon_{C'D'} + \bar{\Psi}_{A'B'C'D'} \bar{\sigma}_{\mu\nu}^{A'B'} \bar{\sigma}_{\rho\sigma}^{C'D'} \epsilon_{AB} \epsilon_{CD}
3075: $$
3076: 
3077: where $\epsilon_{A'B'}$ and $\epsilon_{AB}$ are Levi-Civita symbols contracting the primed indices.
3078: 
3079: **Step 2: Reconstruct trace-free Ricci**
3080: 
3081: $$
3082: S_{\mu\nu} = \Phi_{ABA'B'} \sigma_\mu^{AA'} \sigma_\nu^{BB'}
3083: $$
3084: 
3085: where $\sigma_\mu^{AA'}$ are the soldering forms from {prf:ref}`def-two-spinor-formalism`.
3086: 
3087: **Step 3: Full Ricci tensor**
3088: 
3089: $$
3090: R_{\mu\nu} = S_{\mu\nu} + \frac{1}{4}g_{\mu\nu}R = S_{\mu\nu} + 6\Lambda g_{\mu\nu}
3091: $$
3092: 
3093: where $\Lambda = R/24$.
3094: 
3095: **Step 4: Full Riemann tensor**
3096: 
3097: $$
3098: R^\rho_{\sigma\mu\nu} = C^\rho_{\sigma\mu\nu} + \frac{1}{2}(g^\rho_\mu S_{\sigma\nu} - g^\rho_\nu S_{\sigma\mu} - g_{\sigma\mu} S^\rho_\nu + g_{\sigma\nu} S^\rho_\mu) + \frac{\Lambda}{6}(g^\rho_\mu g_{\sigma\nu} - g^\rho_\nu g_{\sigma\mu})
3099: $$
3100: 
3101: This provides the **bijective inverse map** from spinor back to tensor form.
3102: 
3103: **7. Storage on CST Edges:**
3104: 
3105: Each CST edge $(n_{i,t} \to n_{i,t+1})$ stores:
3106: - $\Psi_R^{(16)}(n_{i,t}) \in \mathbb{C}^{16}$: Full curvature spinor as specified in section 4
3107: - Computed from stored Christoffel symbols $\Gamma^\lambda_{\mu\nu}$ via the Riemann tensor formula:
3108: 
3109: $$
3110: R^\rho_{\sigma\mu\nu} = \partial_\mu \Gamma^\rho_{\nu\sigma} - \partial_\nu \Gamma^\rho_{\mu\sigma} + \Gamma^\rho_{\mu\lambda}\Gamma^\lambda_{\nu\sigma} - \Gamma^\rho_{\nu\lambda}\Gamma^\lambda_{\mu\sigma}
3111: $$
3112: 
3113: then decomposed and encoded into $\Psi_{ABCD}$, $\Phi_{ABA'B'}$, $\Lambda$ using the reconstruction formulas (inverse).
3114: 
3115: **8. Dimension Verification:**
3116: 
3117: $$
3118: \begin{aligned}
3119: \text{Weyl}: & \quad 5 \text{ complex} = 10 \text{ real} \\
3120: \text{Trace-free Ricci}: & \quad 3 \text{ real} + 3 \text{ complex} = 9 \text{ real} \\
3121: \text{Ricci scalar}: & \quad 1 \text{ real} \\
3122: \hline
3123: \text{Total}: & \quad 20 \text{ real components}
3124: \end{aligned}
3125: $$
3126:

hints.label: thm-so10-grand-unification
hints.title: SO(10) Grand Unified Theory from Complete Symmetry Structure
hints.content:
3140: :label: thm-so10-grand-unification
3141: 
3142: The full symmetry structure of the Fractal Set realizes an **SO(10) grand unified theory** that unifies all gauge forces and includes gravity.
3143: 
3144: **1. SO(10) Gauge Group:**
3145: 
3146: The complete gauge symmetry is:
3147: 
3148: $$
3149: G_{\text{GUT}} = \text{SO}(10)
3150: 
3151: $$
3152: 
3153: which contains the gauge forces (note: U(1)_fitness is global, not gauged):
3154: 
3155: $$
3156: \text{SO}(10) \supset \text{SU}(3)_{\text{color}} \times \text{SU}(2)_{\text{weak}} \times [S_N^{\text{discrete}} \times \text{U}(1)_{\text{fitness}}^{\text{global}}]
3157: 
3158: $$
3159: 
3160: **2. Unified State Vector (Spinor Representation):**
3161: 
3162: Each walker state is a **16-component Dirac spinor** in the fundamental representation of SO(10):
3163: 
3164: $$
3165: |\Psi_i^{(\text{SO}(10))}\rangle \in \mathbb{C}^{16}
3166: $$
3167: 
3168: This 16-dimensional spinor is the **irreducible representation** under SO(10) and contains all gauge and gravitational degrees of freedom in a unified, frame-covariant form.
3169: 
3170: **Decomposition under Standard Model subgroup:**
3171: 
3172: Under the chain SO(10) ⊃ SU(5) ⊃ SU(3)×SU(2)×U(1), the 16-spinor decomposes as:
3173: 
3174: $$
3175: \mathbf{16} = \mathbf{10} \oplus \bar{\mathbf{5}} \oplus \mathbf{1}
3176: $$
3177: 
3178: **Algorithmic interpretation:**
3179: - The **color sector** (SU(3), §7.13): Embedded in the 16-spinor via viscous force components
3180: - The **weak sector** (SU(2), §7.10): Embedded via cloning companion selection phases
3181: - The **fitness charge** (U(1), §7.6): Global quantum number, not a gauge DOF in the 16-spinor
3182: - The **gravitational sector**: Encoded via Riemann curvature spinor (§7.14, stored on CST edges)
3183: 
3184: **Key principle:** All 16 components transform **covariantly** under SO(10), preserving frame-independence. The decomposition into gauge sectors emerges from symmetry breaking, not from a direct sum of separate spaces.
3185: 
3186: **3. SO(10) Generators:**
3187: 
3188: The 45 generators of SO(10) form the adjoint representation and decompose under the Standard Model subgroup as:
3189: 
3190: $$
3191: \mathbf{45} = \mathbf{8}_{\text{gluons}} \oplus \mathbf{3}_{\text{weak bosons}} \oplus \mathbf{1}_{\text{B-L}} \oplus \mathbf{24}_{\text{X,Y bosons}} \oplus \text{others}
3192: $$
3193: 
3194: **Gauge structure clarification:**
3195: - **8 generators**: SU(3)_color → gluons (local gauge bosons)
3196: - **3 generators**: SU(2)_weak → W±, Z bosons (local gauge bosons)
3197: - **1 generator**: U(1)_{B-L} → broken symmetry (not U(1)_fitness which is global)
3198: - **24 generators**: X, Y gauge bosons (heavy, broken at GUT scale)
3199: - **Remaining**: Symmetry breaking sector
3200: 
3201: **Discrete symmetry S_N:**
3202: - S_N permutation group acts on walker labels (discrete, not part of SO(10) Lie algebra)
3203: - Provides braid holonomy on Information Graph edges (topological)
3204: - Commutes with SO(10) continuous transformations
3205: 
3206: **Global symmetry U(1)_fitness:**
3207: - Conserved charge (Noether current), not a gauge field
3208: - Does NOT contribute a generator to the 45-dimensional Lie algebra

3137: ### 7.15. SO(10) Grand Unification
3138: 
3139: :::{prf:theorem} SO(10) Grand Unified Theory from Complete Symmetry Structure
3140: :label: thm-so10-grand-unification
3141: 
3142: The full symmetry structure of the Fractal Set realizes an **SO(10) grand unified theory** that unifies all gauge forces and includes gravity.
3143: 
3144: **1. SO(10) Gauge Group:**
3145: 
3146: The complete gauge symmetry is:
3147: 
3148: $$
3149: G_{\text{GUT}} = \text{SO}(10)
3150: 
3151: $$
3152: 
3153: which contains the gauge forces (note: U(1)_fitness is global, not gauged):
3154: 
3155: $$
3156: \text{SO}(10) \supset \text{SU}(3)_{\text{color}} \times \text{SU}(2)_{\text{weak}} \times [S_N^{\text{discrete}} \times \text{U}(1)_{\text{fitness}}^{\text{global}}]
3157: 
3158: $$
3159: 
3160: **2. Unified State Vector (Spinor Representation):**
3161: 
3162: Each walker state is a **16-component Dirac spinor** in the fundamental representation of SO(10):
3163: 
3164: $$
3165: |\Psi_i^{(\text{SO}(10))}\rangle \in \mathbb{C}^{16}
3166: $$
3167: 
3168: This 16-dimensional spinor is the **irreducible representation** under SO(10) and contains all gauge and gravitational degrees of freedom in a unified, frame-covariant form.
3169: 
3170: **Decomposition under Standard Model subgroup:**
3171: 
3172: Under the chain SO(10) ⊃ SU(5) ⊃ SU(3)×SU(2)×U(1), the 16-spinor decomposes as:
3173: 
3174: $$
3175: \mathbf{16} = \mathbf{10} \oplus \bar{\mathbf{5}} \oplus \mathbf{1}
3176: $$
3177: 
3178: **Algorithmic interpretation:**
3179: - The **color sector** (SU(3), §7.13): Embedded in the 16-spinor via viscous force components
3180: - The **weak sector** (SU(2), §7.10): Embedded via cloning companion selection phases
3181: - The **fitness charge** (U(1), §7.6): Global quantum number, not a gauge DOF in the 16-spinor
3182: - The **gravitational sector**: Encoded via Riemann curvature spinor (§7.14, stored on CST edges)
3183: 
3184: **Key principle:** All 16 components transform **covariantly** under SO(10), preserving frame-independence. The decomposition into gauge sectors emerges from symmetry breaking, not from a direct sum of separate spaces.
3185: 
3186: **3. SO(10) Generators:**
3187: 
3188: The 45 generators of SO(10) form the adjoint representation and decompose under the Standard Model subgroup as:
3189: 
3190: $$
3191: \mathbf{45} = \mathbf{8}_{\text{gluons}} \oplus \mathbf{3}_{\text{weak bosons}} \oplus \mathbf{1}_{\text{B-L}} \oplus \mathbf{24}_{\text{X,Y bosons}} \oplus \text{others}
3192: $$
3193: 
3194: **Gauge structure clarification:**
3195: - **8 generators**: SU(3)_color → gluons (local gauge bosons)
3196: - **3 generators**: SU(2)_weak → W±, Z bosons (local gauge bosons)
3197: - **1 generator**: U(1)_{B-L} → broken symmetry (not U(1)_fitness which is global)
3198: - **24 generators**: X, Y gauge bosons (heavy, broken at GUT scale)
3199: - **Remaining**: Symmetry breaking sector
3200: 
3201: **Discrete symmetry S_N:**
3202: - S_N permutation group acts on walker labels (discrete, not part of SO(10) Lie algebra)
3203: - Provides braid holonomy on Information Graph edges (topological)
3204: - Commutes with SO(10) continuous transformations
3205: 
3206: **Global symmetry U(1)_fitness:**
3207: - Conserved charge (Noether current), not a gauge field
3208: - Does NOT contribute a generator to the 45-dimensional Lie algebra
3209:

hints.label: def-so10-generator-matrices
hints.title: SO(10) Generator Matrices in Spinor Representation
hints.content:
3214: :label: def-so10-generator-matrices
3215: 
3216: The 45 generators of SO(10) acting on the 16-dimensional spinor $|\Psi\rangle \in \mathbb{C}^{16}$ are represented by 16×16 matrices constructed from **Dirac gamma matrices in 10 dimensions**.
3217: 
3218: **1. Gamma Matrix Basis:**
3219: 
3220: In 10D, we have 10 Dirac gamma matrices $\Gamma^A$ (A = 0,1,...,9) satisfying the Clifford algebra:
3221: 
3222: $$
3223: \{\Gamma^A, \Gamma^B\} = 2\eta^{AB}
3224: $$
3225: 
3226: where $\eta^{AB} = \text{diag}(-1,+1,+1,...,+1)$ is the 10D Minkowski metric.
3227: 
3228: **Representation:** Each $\Gamma^A$ is a 16×16 matrix. The 16-component spinor is the **Weyl (chiral) spinor** in 10D.
3229: 
3230: **2. SO(10) Generator Construction:**
3231: 
3232: The 45 generators are antisymmetric combinations:
3233: 
3234: $$
3235: T^{AB} = \frac{1}{4}[\Gamma^A, \Gamma^B] = \frac{1}{4}(\Gamma^A \Gamma^B - \Gamma^B \Gamma^A), \quad A < B
3236: $$
3237: 
3238: This gives $\binom{10}{2} = 45$ independent generators.
3239: 
3240: **Properties:**
3241: - Antisymmetric: $T^{AB} = -T^{BA}$
3242: - Satisfy SO(10) commutation relations: $[T^{AB}, T^{CD}] = \eta^{AC}T^{BD} - \eta^{AD}T^{BC} - \eta^{BC}T^{AD} + \eta^{BD}T^{AC}$
3243: - Act on 16-spinor: $T^{AB} |\Psi\rangle \in \mathbb{C}^{16}$
3244: 
3245: **3. Explicit 10D Gamma Matrices (Weyl Basis):**
3246: 
3247: In the Weyl (chiral) basis, the 10D gamma matrices can be constructed from 4D gamma matrices via:
3248: 
3249: $$
3250: \Gamma^0 = \gamma^0 \otimes I_4 \otimes \sigma_3, \quad
3251: \Gamma^i = \gamma^i \otimes I_4 \otimes \sigma_3 \quad (i=1,2,3)
3252: $$
3253: $$
3254: \Gamma^{4+a} = \gamma^5 \otimes \sigma^a \otimes \sigma_1 \quad (a=1,2,3,4,5,6)
3255: $$
3256: 
3257: where:
3258: - $\gamma^\mu$ are 4D Dirac matrices (4×4)
3259: - $\gamma^5 = i\gamma^0\gamma^1\gamma^2\gamma^3$ is the chirality operator
3260: - $\sigma^a$ are generalized Pauli matrices in higher dimensions
3261: - $I_4$ is the 4×4 identity matrix
3262: 
3263: **4. Decomposition Under Standard Model:**
3264: 
3265: Under SO(10) ⊃ SU(3)×SU(2)×U(1), the 45 generators decompose as:
3266: 
3267: **SU(3) generators (8 matrices):**
3268: $$
3269: T^{SU(3)}_a = \frac{1}{4}[\Gamma^{i}, \Gamma^{j}], \quad a = 1,...,8 \quad (i,j \in \{1,2,3\})
3270: $$
3271: 
3272: These embed the Gell-Mann matrices $\lambda_a$ in the 16-spinor.
3273: 
3274: **SU(2) generators (3 matrices):**
3275: $$
3276: T^{SU(2)}_a = \frac{1}{4}[\Gamma^{4+a}, \Gamma^{4+b}], \quad a = 1,2,3 \quad (a \neq b)
3277: $$
3278: 
3279: These embed the Pauli matrices $\sigma_a$ in the 16-spinor.
3280: 
3281: **U(1)_{B-L} generator (1 matrix):**
3282: $$
3283: T^{U(1)} = \frac{1}{4}\sum_{A=5}^{9} \Gamma^A \Gamma^{A+1}
3284: $$
3285: 
3286: This is the hypercharge generator (Baryon minus Lepton number).
3287: 
3288: **X, Y bosons (24 matrices):**
3289: The remaining 33 generators connect different SM sectors (lepto-quark transitions).
3290: 
3291: **Gravitational embedding (distributed across all 45):**
3292: The curvature spinor $\Psi_R$ transforms under the full SO(10) via all 45 generators, not a separate subspace.
3293: 
3294: **5. Action on Walker States:**
3295: 
3296: For a walker with state $|\Psi_i\rangle \in \mathbb{C}^{16}$, an infinitesimal SO(10) transformation is:
3297: 
3298: $$
3299: |\Psi_i\rangle \to |\Psi_i'\rangle = \left(I_{16} + i\sum_{A<B} \theta^{AB} T^{AB}\right) |\Psi_i\rangle
3300: $$
3301: 
3302: where $\theta^{AB}$ are 45 real parameters (transformation angles).
3303: 
3304: **Finite transformations:**
3305: $$
3306: |\Psi_i\rangle \to U|\Psi_i\rangle, \quad U = \exp\left(i\sum_{A<B} \theta^{AB} T^{AB}\right) \in SO(10)
3307: $$
3308: 
3309: **6. Numerical Representation (Explicit Matrices):**
3310: 
3311: The complete 16×16 matrices for all 45 generators can be computed from the gamma matrix products. For algorithmic implementation, the standard Weyl basis provides:
3312: 
3313: **Example: $T^{01}$ (boost in t-x plane):**
3314: $$
3315: T^{01} = \frac{1}{4}[\Gamma^0, \Gamma^1] = \frac{1}{4}(\Gamma^0\Gamma^1 - \Gamma^1\Gamma^0) \in \mathbb{C}^{16 \times 16}
3316: $$
3317: 
3318: This is a 16×16 matrix that mixes spinor components corresponding to time-space transformations.
3319: 
3320: **Storage in Fractal Set:**
3321: - Each CST edge stores the **gauge connection**: $A_{AB}^\mu(n_{i,t}) \in \mathbb{R}^{45}$

hints.label: thm-so10-covariant-derivative
hints.title: SO(10) Covariant Derivative and Spinor Transformation
hints.content:
3327: :label: thm-so10-covariant-derivative
3328: 
3329: The walker state $|\Psi_i(t)\rangle \in \mathbb{C}^{16}$ evolves covariantly under SO(10) via:
3330: 
3331: $$
3332: \frac{d|\Psi_i\rangle}{dt} = -i\sum_{A<B} A_{AB}^\mu(x_i) \frac{dx_i^\mu}{dt} \, T^{AB} |\Psi_i\rangle
3333: $$
3334: 
3335: where:
3336: - $A_{AB}^\mu$: SO(10) gauge connection (45 components at each spacetime point)
3337: - $dx_i^\mu/dt = v_i^\mu$: Walker 4-velocity
3338: - $T^{AB}$: SO(10) generators (16×16 matrices from {prf:ref}`def-so10-generator-matrices`)
3339: 
3340: **Frame-covariance:** Under SO(10) gauge transformation $U(x)$:
3341: $$
3342: |\Psi\rangle \to U|\Psi\rangle, \quad A_{AB}^\mu \to U A_{AB}^\mu U^{-1} + \frac{i}{g}(\partial^\mu U) U^{-1}
3343: $$

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-2786
hints.title: Complete Fractal Set as Grand Unified Field Theory
hints.content:
3413: :class: important
3414: 
3415: The **Fractal Set** encodes a complete **SU(3) × SU(2) × U(1) grand unified field theory** with the following identifications:
3416: 
3417: | **Physics Concept** | **Fractal Set Realization** | **Algorithmic Origin** | **Section** |
3418: |---------------------|------------------------------|------------------------|-------------|
3419: | **U(1)_fitness** | Diversity self-measurement phase | Diversity companion selection | §7.6 |
3420: | **SU(2)_weak** | Weak isospin doublet interaction | Cloning companion selection | §7.10 |
3421: | **Higgs field** | Reward scalar $r(x)$ | Position-dependent fitness potential | §7.11 |
3422: | **SU(3)_color** | Viscous force three-vector | Momentum-phase encoding | §7.12 |
3423: | **Fermions** | Walkers (antisymmetric cloning) | Pauli exclusion from antisymmetry | §7.13 |
3424: | **General Relativity** | Emergent curved manifold $g_{\mu\nu}$ | Fitness Hessian curvature | §7.14 |
3425: | **SO(10) GUT** | Unified 16-component spinor | Complete gauge unification | §7.15 |
3426: 
3427: **Gauge Group Structure**:
3428: $$
3429: G = \text{SU}(3)_{\text{color}} \times \text{SU}(2)_{\text{weak}} \times \text{U}(1)_{\text{fitness}}
3430: $$
3431: 
3432: This directly parallels the Standard Model gauge group (with U(1)_fitness replacing U(1)_Y).
3433: 
3434: **Status**: This is a **complete particle physics analogue** embedded in the algorithmic structure of the Adaptive Gas.
3435: 
3436: **Testable predictions**:
3437: 1. Wilson loops measure confinement/deconfinement phase transition
3438: 2. Higgs VEV $\langle r \rangle$ correlates with algorithm convergence
